title: Guy Mannering
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: It was a hedge alehouse, where the Bolder farmersof either country often stopped to refresh themselves and theirnags, in their way to and from the fairs and trysts in Cumberland,and especially those who came from or went to Scotland, through abarren and lonely district, without either road or pathway,emphatically called the Waste of Bewcastle.

title: Guy Mannering
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: An' I forgat to tell ye, there's been anunco inquiry after the auld wife that we saw in Bewcastle; theSheriffs had folk ower the Limestane Edge after her, and down theHermitage and Liddel, and a' gates, and a reward offered for her toappear, o' fifty pound sterling, nae less; and justice Forster,he's had out warrants, as I am tell'd, in Cumberland, and an uncoranging and riping [*A Searching.] they have had a' gates seekingfor her; but she'll no be taen wi' them unless she likes, for a'that."

title: Guy Mannering
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: She stepped back a pace, and he entered, instantlyrecognising, but with no comfortable sensation, the same gipsywoman whom he had met in Bewcastle.

title: Guy Mannering
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: There's noane in Bewcastle would do the like o' that now--we be a' true folknow."

title: Guy Mannering, Or, the Astrologer - Volume 02
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: An' I forgat to tell ye, there's been anunco inquiry after the auld wife that we saw in Bewcastle; theSheriff's had folk ower the Limestane Edge after her, and down theHermitage and Liddel, and a' gates, and a reward offered for herto appear o' fifty pound sterling, nae less; and Justice Forster,he's had out warrants, as I am tell'd, in Cumberland; and an uncoranging and ripeing they have had a' gates seeking for her; butshe'll no be taen wi' them unless she likes, for a' that.'

title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: The Thirlwalls, the Ridleys, the Howards ofNaworth, the wild men of Bewcastle; the Armstrongs, Elliots, Scotts, andothers across the Border, they were all of them--they and theirforebears to the earliest times--of the stuff that prefers action,however stormy, to inglorious peace and quiet, and the man who "kept uphis end" in their neighbourhood could be no weakling.

title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: The Thirlwalls, the Ridleys, the Howards ofNaworth, the wild men of Bewcastle; the Armstrongs, Elliots, Scotts, andothers across the Border, they were all of them--they and theirforebears to the earliest times--of the stuff that prefers action,however stormy, to inglorious peace and quiet, and the man who "kept uphis end" in their neighbourhood could be no weakling.

title: The recreations of Christopher North
author: Wilson, John
snippet: Out comes the master, a rosy-cheeked carle, upwards of six feet high, broad-shouldered, with a blue bonnet and velveteen breeches — a man not to be jostled on the crown o' the causey, and a match for any horse-couper from Bewcastle, or gipsy from Yetholm.

title: Last leaves;
author: Smith, Alexander
snippet: With their number augmented, they ride forward,  and in a short time come in sight of the Captain of Bewcastle and his men driving the booty straight for England.

title: Last leaves;
author: Smith, Alexander
snippet: The Captain of Bewcastle had carried off Jamie's cattle, and the ruined man starts up, " leaving a greeting wife and bairnies three," and runs ten miles afoot over the new fallen snow to summon aid.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The crown appears frequently tohave maintained garrisons there, besides the retinue which was assigned to the wardens, as also atAskerton in Bewcastle, Naworth, and other placesof strength.
